SEARCH
Package com.oblong.jelly

Class SlawIO

java.lang.Object
com.oblong.jelly.SlawIO
public final class SlawIO extends Object
Utilities for serializing Slaw instances to files, strings and byte arrays.

Serialization can be piecemeal, via a SlawWriter instance, or performed in a single, atomic operation using write(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw[], java.lang.String, com.oblong.jelly.SlawIO.Format). Reading the resulting data can be accomplished via a Slaw iterator, i.e., an instance of SlawReader. It's also possible to read all slawx in one shot using read(java.lang.String).

Slawx can be serialized in any of the formats enumerated by SlawIO.Format, which will be automatically recognised by readers.

The binary output is in the same format used to store slawx in pools, plus a short header. As such, it's highly compact and, well, binary, which means that is not apt for general human consumption.

YAML output uses the YAML 1.1 format, with some Oblong-specific tags. Every YAML file (or output string) starts with a couple of directives spelling that out: 

   %YAML 1.1
   %TAG ! tag:oblong.com,2009:slaw/
followed by one or more YAML "documents". Each document starts with the string "--- ", followed by the slaw value.

Integer Slaw use special tags to denote their precise type. E.g.: 

   --- !u8 23
   --- !i32 -23943
   --- !f64 2.34341E23
Other atomic types use regular YAML tags, with NIL represented by !!null: 
   --- !!str "This is a \"string\""
   --- !string Also a string
   --- !!bool true
   --- !!null
Numeric containers are represented as sequences of its components: 
   --- !complex [!i32 3, !i32 -23]
   --- !vector [!i8 1, !i8 2]
   --- !vector [!i16 1, !i16 2, !i16 3, !i16 4]
   --- !array [!vector [!i8 0, !i8 1], !vector [!i8 2, !i8 3]]
As you see, you don't need to specify the numeric ilk of the container, except in the case of empty arrays, which use special tags starting with "!empty", as in !empty/i16 for an empty array of INT16s, or !empty/vector/3/complex/u8 for a COMPLEX_VECTOR_ARRAY with numeric ilk UNT8. Lists are encoded using a standard YAML sequence, which can be represented either inline: 
   --- !!seq [!u8 0, !!str "a string", !!null, !!bool false]
or in block form: --- !!seq - !u8 0 - !!str a string - !!null - !! bool false Slaw maps are externalized as a YAML ordered map (!!omap), which is a sequence of maps with just one key/value pair: 
   ---- !!omap
   - !!str key : !i8 1969
   - !null : !complex [!u16 1, !u16 2]
while conses use the non-standard tag !cons and are represented as a map with one entry: its key is the cons' car and, its value, the cdr.

Finally, proteins use !protein and as represented as (non-ordered) maps with ingests, descrips and rude_data as keys, the latter containing the protein's extra data encoded in base64 and tagged as !!binary: 

   --- !protein
   descrips: !!seq [!cons {!!str bat : !!str bi}, !i8 2]
   ingests: !!omap
      - key1: !i8 1
      - key2: !i32 123231
   rude_data: !!binary |-
      AAECAwQFBgcICQoLDA0ODxAREhMUFRYXGA==

  • Method Details

    • reader

      public static SlawReader reader(String fileName) throws IOException
      Factory method creating a reader associated with a file, given its path.

      The reader will recognise the format of the data (binary or YAML) automatically.

      Throws:
      IOException - is the requested file does not exist or cannot be read for any other reason.
      See Also:
      • for atomically reading all slawx in a file.
      • stringReader(java.lang.String)
      • reader(byte[])
      • SlawReader

    • reader

      public static SlawReader reader(byte[] data)
      A reader getting its data from a given byte array.
      See Also:
      • reader(String)
      • SlawReader

    • stringReader

      public static SlawReader stringReader(String data)
      A reader getting its data from a given string. Equivalent to calling reader(byte[]) with data.getBytes().

    • read

      public static List<Slaw> read(String fileName) throws IOException
      Convenience method reading all slawx in the given file and returning them as a list. If the file does not contain any Slaw or is not in a recognisable format, the returned list will be empty.
      Throws:
      IOException - is the requested file does not exist or cannot be read for any other reason.

    • fromString

      public static List<Slaw> fromString(String yaml) throws IOException
      De-serialize a list of Slawx serialized in YAML format with toString.
      Throws:
      IOException - if the input cannot be decoded.

    • fromBytes

      public static List<Slaw> fromBytes(byte[] bin) throws IOException
      De-serialize a list of Slawx serialized in YAML format with toBytes(com.oblong.jelly.Slaw[]).
      Throws:
      IOException - if the input cannot be decoded.

    • writer

      public static SlawWriter writer(String fileName, SlawIO.Format format) throws IOException
      Factory method creating a writer associated with the given file. The file will be created or, if it exists, truncated to zero length. If the given format is YAML, the default SlawIO.YamlOptions will be used.
      Throws:
      IOException - when the file cannot be created or written to.
      See Also:
      • for atomically writing an array of Slawx without using an intermediate writer.
      • SlawWriter

    • writer

      public static SlawWriter writer(String fileName, SlawIO.YamlOptions opts) throws IOException
      Factory method creating a writer with output to the given file and YAML format. The second argument allows fine tunning of the output, and can be safely null to use the default options.
      Throws:
      IOException - when the file cannot be created or written to.
      See Also:
      • for atomically writing an array of Slawx without using an intermediate writer.
      • for serializing to a string instead of a file.
      • SlawWriter

    • write

      public static boolean write(Slaw[] slawx, String fileName, SlawIO.Format format) throws IOException
      Convenience method writing an array of slawx in one shot. If the given file exists, it'll be overwritten.

      For YAML output, you can also use this write method.

      Throws:
      IOException - when the file cannot be created or written to. Otherwise, the return value indicates whether all slawx were written.

    • toBytes

      public static byte[] toBytes(Slaw[] slawx)
      Convenience method serializing an array of slawx to a bytes, in binary format.
      See Also:

    • write

      public static boolean write(Slaw[] slawx, String fileName, SlawIO.YamlOptions opts) throws IOException
      Convenience method writing an array of slawx in one shot, in YAML format, with the specified options. If the given file exists, it'll be overwritten.
      Throws:
      IOException - when the file cannot be created or written to. Otherwise, the return value indicates whether all slawx were written.
      See Also:
      • for serializing to a string instead of a file.
